sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for the traditional classification of Arabic varieties.

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found
updating references to Zotero IDs via update-bibl-refs.xsl

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Sabuni (1980:VII): "Die vorliegende Untersuchung behandelt einen neuarabischen Dialekt, der zu den Stadtdialekten des syrisch-libanesisch-palästinischen Sprachtypus gehört.
It is referred to as a qəltu dialect.
It is referred to as a qəltu dialect.
It is referred to as a qəltu dialect.
It is referred to as a qəltu dialect.

Rosenhouse (2007): "Jerusalem Arabic is an urban dialect within the larger dialect area of aš-Šām, which extends from Syria to Lebanon, Israel, and Jordan. The dialects of this region are part of the Eastern dialects within the Arabic-speaking world."
Khuzestani Arabic is a South-Mesopotamian Bedouin-type dialect and generally classified among the gələt-type group of dialects (Leitner 2022:17).

Woidich (2006:3): "Dialektologisch zählt das Kairenische im engeren ägyptischen Rahmen zu den Dialekten des zentralen Niltals (...) im weiteren Rahmen zu den ostarabischen prähilalischen Dialekten und steht damit den syrisch-palästinensischen Stadtdialekten relative nahe.

" the variety under analysis definitely belongs to the ca tegory of village dialects, yet it shows the signs of a diachronic develop ment that might have occurred in Chebba or in the host town." (D'Anna 2018:70)

"BA is a mixed dialect, as it displays both Bedouin and urban features. Though the earlier studies record that early 20th century BA already had both urban and Bedouin features, the fact that even more Bedouin features appear in the dialect spoken today is no doubt the result of the massive migration of speakers of Bedouin varieties to Benghazi in the second half of the 20th century, where their varieties mixed with the pre‑existing, slightly more urban dialect of Benghazi. The mass influx of Bedouin forms on top of these earlier urban ones has also resulted in either a) a few features which are some sort of merged Bedouin/urban form, b) the coexistence of both forms simultaneously, or c) confusion as to which form is more correct. This mixed aspect appears throughout the dialect’s phonetic, syntactic, and morphological systems, as well as in the lexicon. Nevertheless, as P. MARÇAIS already pointed out, Benghazi Arabic, like nearly all dialects of Libya, is remarkably conservative (MARÇAIS 1977: ix)... Thus it may be said that the Arabic dialect of Benghazi is overall a Bedouin dialect, with some features from an older, slightly more urbanized variety. As a result of the intense migration of rural Bedouin from eastern Libya to Benghazi, BA has been influenced by a number of Bedouin features." (Benkato 2014: 92-93, 95)

"Comme le remarquait W. Marcais, le Fezzān semble bien constituer une entité, avec des traits communs aux nomades et aux sédentaires, pour ce qui est du lexique et d'une partie de la morphologie" (Caubet 2004:92)
"Like many other Libyan dialects, the Arabic spoken in Miṣrāta is a mixed variety, featuring (prevalent) Bedouin traits alongside sedentary ones." (D'Anna 2017:156)

"The only pre-Hilali dialects whose presence is attested in the country in modern times, in fact, are all Judeo-Arabic varieties... When seen from a broader Maghrebi perspective, LJA shows considerable continuity with the neighboring sedentary dialects of Tunisia. These traits are to be historically interpreted as signs of a more homogeneous stage in the linguistic history of Eastern North Africa, before the Hilali migrations of the 11th century profoundly changed the dialect landscape of Libya." (D'Anna 2021:1-2,29)
" it is not a bedouin dialect but rather a dialect of sedentary people who live in small towns and villages" (Harrama 1993:13)
"the variety spoken in the Nefza region nowadays can be classified as a Bedouin-type variety with an increasing influence of Tunisian sedentary varieties." (Naddari 2023:253)
"Today, the spoken Arabic of Tripoli may be considered a Bedouin dialect with certain pre-Hilalian urban characteristics." (Pereira 2011)
"Le parler arabe de Tripoli est un parler arabe urbain en pleine mutation" (Pereira 2010:17)
"The dialects spoken in the Arabian Peninsula, except its southwestern parts, are Bedouin or former Bedouin dialects." (Palva 2006:611)

"The only pre-Hilali dialects whose presence is attested in the country in modern times, in fact, are all Judeo-Arabic varieties" (D'Anna 2021:1-2)
" Algiers Arabic marks the boundary between the Eastern and Western Maghrebi dialects; it is classified in the urban pre-Hilālī dialectal group"
"Bedouin-based urban dialect" p.291

It has been said that this is a city whose variety is Bedouin, but which maintains an important number of peculiarities that distance it in some way from other varieties of the area also considered Bedouin. (translated, p.10)
hilali type dialect, p.9
"the spoken Arabic of Constantine is a dialect of mixed affinities" p.7
The dialect can be classified as more Bedouin than sedentary, even though the speakers identify as sedentary.
